ab.b:
On Reflection, Radiance, Gloss or Luster.
The Seventh Chapter.

div.ab:
1. Speaking of reflection or luster,
we must begin with the radiance of the Sun.
for one sees its light, stand out above all;
all stars would lack clarity
without the reflection of the sun,
which bestows on the sky its beautiful aspect.
It is the Worldâ€™s Soul in the midst of the Planets;
we should not forget it in our purposes.

2. When night, with its black sails of dark omens,
needs to retreat from the field,
and unveils once again beautiful things
in all places on the Face of the earth,
then one can see in the shadowy clouds
a Radiance, or luster,
as the Sun comes to bring joy with the day
and spreads the Light with many colors.

3. It is a delight for heart and mind
in the dawn, before one sees appearing
the principal light of the Earth with golden rays,
to see the azure fields of the Orient
sown with red Roses and purple Flowers;
How can one find a more beautiful Reflection,
which many Poets in earlier times
have described with painterly art?
right-middleAurora is the redness both of morning and evening.

4. Of Aurora (as the Poet says)
Cephalus told stories to Phocus,
How she was seated on Mount Hymettus,
Which is perpetually in bloom;
Her mouth was red beyond Coral,
and that in rising and setting, she always
honors the morning and evening,
bestowing on them the first and last light.

early in the morning and late in the evening,
